facts.text: Since 1958 the State of Mysore has been endeavouring to make a special provision for the advancement of the socially and educationally backward classes of citizens in the State of Mysore under Article 15(4) of the Constitution.
Four previous orders passed by the State under Art. 15(4) were challenged by writ proceedings under Art. 226 in the High Court of Mysore.
Present petitions under Art. 32 challenge the order passed by the State of Mysore on July 31, 1962 under Art. 15(4).

Out of the twenty-three petitioners, six had applied for admission to the Pre-professional Class in Medicine in the Medical Colleges affiliated either to the Mysore University or to the Karnatak University, and seventeen had applied for admission to the First Year of the 5 Year integrated course leading to the Degree of B.E. in the University of Mysore.
According to the petitioners, but for the reservation made by the impugned order, they would have been entitled to admission in the respective colleges for which they had applied.
As a result of the reservation made by the said order, students who have secured less percentage of marks have been admitted, but not the petitioners.

On 26th July 1958, the State issued an order that all communities, excepting the Brahmin community, fell within the definition of educationally and socially Backward Classes and Scheduled Castes and Tribes, and provided for reservation of 75% of seats in educational institutions (15% for Scheduled Castes, 3% for Scheduled Tribes).
The 1958 order was challenged before the Mysore High Court; State conceded drafting error and order was quashed.

In 1959, two separate orders on 14th May and 22nd July classified all communities except Brahmins, Baniyas and Kayasts among the Hindus and Muslims, Christians and Jains as socially and educationally Backward Classes, reserving 65% of seats.
1959 orders challenged in Ramakrishna Singh v. State of Mysore; High Court quashed them and directed admissions without reference to those orders but subject to SC/ST reservation.
State appointed Mysore Backward Classes Committee (Dr. R. Nagan Gowda Chairman); interim report led to order on 9th June 1960: 60% merit pool, 40% reservation (22% Backward Classes, 15% SC, 3% ST).
1960 order challenged in S.A. Partha v. State of Mysore; High Court upheld scheme but invalidated excess reservation for Backward Classes beyond open competition.

Nagan Gowda Committee final report in 1961 led to order on July 10, 1961: Backward Classes sub-divided into Backward (30%) and More Backward; total reservation 48% (30% BC, 15% SC, 3% ST); list of 81 Backward and 135 More Backward Classes.
Impugned order on July 31, 1962 supersedes previous: 50% for Other Backward Classes (28% Backward, 22% More Backward), plus 15% SC, 3% ST; total 68% reservation, 32% merit pool.

Backward Classes Commission appointed January 29, 1953 under Art. 340(1); report March 30, 1955; criteria: occupation, literacy, population, social position, etc.; recommended 70% reservation in technical institutions.
Chairman of Backward Classes Commission dissented on caste basis.
Central Government memorandum rejected caste-based approach.
Central Government letter April 24, 1962 to Mysore: reservations not exceed 35%; All-India Council recommended up to 25% +10%.

Nagan Gowda Committee: caste main basis for social backwardness; educational test: average student population in last three high school classes <6.9/1000 backward, <50% more backward; recommended 68% total reservation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the impugned order dated July 31, 1962 passed under Art. 15(4) is valid, particularly the basis of classification of socially and educationally backward classes and the extent of reservation (68%).
Whether the State can make special provision under Art. 15(4) by executive order without a Commission under Art. 340.
Whether the classification is based solely on caste, rendering it invalid under Art. 15(4).
Whether 68% reservation is excessive and a fraud on Art. 15(4).

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned order invalid as basis for specifying backward classes is unintelligible and irrational, classification inconsistent with Art. 15(4).
Extent of reservation (68%) unreasonable and extravagant, amounting to fraud on power under Art. 15(4).
State incompetent to act under Art. 15(4) without Commission under Art. 340(1) and laying report before Parliament.
Special provision must be by legislation, not executive order.

respondent_arguments.text: Classification made is both rational and intelligible; reservation fully justified by Art. 15(4).
Order is colourable exercise of State's power, not fraud on Constitution.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 15(4) does not require prior Commission under Art. 340 or legislation; State (including executive) can act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appointment of Commission not condition precedent; recommendations for Union/State action.

court_reasoning.text: Backwardness must be both social and educational, not relative to most advanced; caste relevant but not sole/dominant test.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification solely on caste impermissible; must consider poverty, occupation, habitation etc.

court_reasoning.text: Impugned order and Nagan Gowda Committee used caste as sole/practicable basis, invalid.
Educational test (student population near State average 6.9-7.1/1000) flawed; communities at/near average not backward (e.g., Lingayats 7.1, Ganigas 7).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only well below average qualify; sub-classification Backward/More Backward unwarranted.

court_reasoning.text: 68% reservation excessive; special provision must be reasonable, less than 50%, balance weaker sections with society/merit/national interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot exclude merit pool entirely; prior State view (1961 order) rejected 68%.

court_reasoning.text: Order is fraud on Constitution as patently outside Art. 15(4) limits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Substance over form; caste basis and excess reservation transgress power.

holdings.text: Impugned order invalid under Art. 15(4) due to caste-based classification and excessive 68% reservation.
State can make executive order under Art. 15(4) without Art. 340 Commission.
Reservation under Art. 15(4) must be reasonable, generally less than 50%.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan
precedents_cited.relevance: Led to insertion of Art. 15(4); communal G.O. invalid pre-amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramakrishna Singh v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Quashed 1959 orders classifying most communities as backward.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.A. Partha v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld 1960 scheme but invalidated excess reservation beyond open competition.

precedents_cited.case_name: General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 16(4) allows reservation of selection posts; analogous to Art. 15(4), must be reasonable.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 15(4) enables special provision for backward classes as exception to 15(1)/29(2); must be reasonable; Art. 340 not mandatory precondition.

outcome.summary: Writ petitions allowed; impugned order of July 31, 1962 quashed as invalid under Art. 15(4) due to caste-based classification and excessive reservation; respondents restrained from implementing it.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of mandamus or suitable direction restraining respondents from enforcing the order.

key_quotes.text: the only practicable method of classifying the Backward Classes in the State is on the basis of castes and communities
key_quotes.speaker: respondent
key_quotes.significance: Preamble of July 10, 1961 order admitting caste basis, held invalid by court.

key_quotes.text: Social backwardness is on the ultimate analysis the result of poverty, to a very large extent.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's view on proper test for social backwardness beyond caste.

key_quotes.text: a special provision should be less than 50%; how much less than 50 would depend upon the relevant prevailing circumstances in each case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Guideline on quantum of reservation under Art. 15(4).

key_quotes.text: the impugned order is a fraud on the Constitutional power conferred on the State by Art. 15(4).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final holding on invalidity of the order.
